title: 108_hr1079
content: The "Neutral Cost Recovery Act for Small Business" may be cited as the Act. It includes increased expensing for small businesses. The "Neutral Cost Recovery Act for Small Business" increases the expensing limit for small businesses. The dollar limitation for aggregate cost under section 179(b) of the Internal Revenue Code is set at $75,000, with a phaseout threshold of $325,000. Section 179 property includes tangible property as defined in section 168. The "Neutral Cost Recovery Act for Small Business" raises the expensing limit for small businesses under section 179 of the Internal Revenue Code. It includes tangible property, computer software, and section 1245 property acquired for business use. The dollar limitation and phaseout threshold are subject to inflation adjustments after 2003. Beginning in a calendar year after 2003, the dollar amounts in paragraphs (1) and (2) shall each be increased by an amount equal to the cost-of-living adjustment for that year. If the increased amount is not a multiple of $1,000 or $10,000, it shall be rounded accordingly. The taxpayer can revoke an election under paragraph (1) for any property, and once revoked, it is irrevocable. These amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2002. Neutral cost recovery depreciation adjustment for certain property placed in service after December 31, 2003. Deduction adjustment to allow equivalent of expensing for certain property placed in service after December 31, 2003, under Section 168 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The applicable neutral cost recovery ratio for property placed in service after December 31, 2003, is determined by dividing the gross domestic product deflator for the quarter when the property was placed in service by the taxpayer by the deflator for the corresponding quarter. The applicable neutral cost recovery ratio is calculated by dividing the gross domestic product deflator for the quarter when the property was placed in service by the taxpayer by the deflator for the corresponding quarter, and then multiplying by 1.035 to the nth power where 'n' is the number of full years in the period. The ratio shall never be less than 1 and is rounded to the nearest \1/1000\. The neutral cost recovery ratio is determined by dividing the gross domestic product deflator for the quarter when the property was placed in service by the deflator for the corresponding quarter, then multiplying by 1.035 to the nth power. The ratio is rounded to the nearest \1/1000\ and shall not be less than 1. Special rules apply for certain properties, and there is an option to elect not to have this subsection apply. The additional deduction under this section does not affect the adjusted basis of any property or interest in a pass-thru entity. The term 'pass-thru entity' includes regulated investment companies, real estate investment trusts, S corporations, partnerships, estates or trusts, and common trust funds. The minimum tax treatment for property placed in service after December 31, 2003, under section 168(k) applies to partnerships, estates or trusts, and common trust funds. The deduction allowable for such property in any taxable year is determined by multiplying the allowable amount by the applicable neutral cost recovery ratio. The amendments made by this section relate to the coordination with depreciation limitation on certain automobiles under the tax code. It includes adjustments to the neutral cost recovery deduction and the treatment of unrecovered basis for passenger automobiles. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years ending after December 31, 2003.
